awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Intelligent and Scalable Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The Intelligent and Scalable Systems Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site provides an inspirational and successful research experience for 10 undergraduate students over a 10 week period at Lehigh University. Over the summer, participants learn how to harness the incredible potential of machine learning, and the unprecedented power of modern parallel compute resources, to invent new systems and algorithms that are infused with intelligence and hence capable of solving pressing societal problems. The proposed REU Site employs a multifaceted recruiting strategy, with a focus on encouraging women, underrepresented, and minority students to participate; a special focus will be placed on recruiting from institutions that lack undergraduate research opportunities. Students will also benefit from a program of seminars and tutorials designed to ensure that they are ready to collaborate, knowledgeable about the key concepts and technologies in modern intelligent and scalable systems, and inspired to pursue both further education and life-long careers in Computer Science.

The objective of this ten-week summer research experience is to increase the number and diversity of students pursuing graduate degrees in computer science, around the timely theme of intelligent and scalable systems.   This REU Site will facilitate research into fundamental topics in both machine learning and scalable computer systems, such as new algorithms for machine learning, new approaches to privacy preservation, and new techniques for increasing the performance of parallel programs. It will also support application-focused research, with an emphasis on creating solutions to hard problems in both research and society. Through seminars and faculty-supervised collaborative projects, participants will learn about the research process, hone their software development skills, improve their comfort with technical communication, become knowledgeable about graduate school and its application process, and ultimately develop greater confidence in their ability to succeed in a Science/Technology/Engineering/Math career.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The "Intelligent and Scalable Systems" REU Site at Lehigh University was operational over three summers, from 2018-2020 plus a no-cost extension to accommodate any subsequent publication costs.  

The project had three goals: 1) To offer an REU Site focusing on the intersection of machine learning and parallel computing; 2) To create an opportunity for undergraduate students to pair instruction with research mentorship; and, 3) To appeal to and recruit students from small schools, with a focus on recruiting students whose gender or ethnicity is underrepresented in computing disciplines.

Over the three operational years (including the last one held fully remotely because of COVID), we received a total of 311 applications, from whom we recruited and supported 32 students.  34.4% of the students were women or non-binary participants, and when disregarding gender, 31.3% were from groups underrepresented in computing.  65.6% of students were from schools lacking significant research opportunities.

Development of human resources is the primary outcome of any Research Experience for Undergraduates site. Over our three summer sessions, 32 students experienced the research process, built relationships with Lehigh CSE faculty and other students on the same (and other) projects, were exposed to graduate life, interacted with current doctoral students, learned how to apply to graduate school, became familiar with research tools and techniques, and more.  Over forty percent of our participants went on to graduate programs (ten students went directly into doctoral programs, and three into master's programs).

Eleven publications so far have resulted from work performed by students in the REU site in 2018-2020.  Such publications enabled students to have the experience of presenting their work to a new and larger audience.  In some cases, these publications may have been valuable performance markers when applying to graduate school.  Some of the publications resulted from cutting edge research.  We briefly describe three here:

Spamming reviews are prevalent in review systems to manipulate seller reputation and mislead customers, and detection of such patterns is essential.  However, typical mechanisms to detect such reviews can fail to meet diverse fairness criteria designed for different parties. This work, supervised by Prof. Sihong Xie and published at the 30th ACM International Conference on Information & Knowledge Management (CIKM) in 2021, demonstrates that a multi-objective optimization algorithm that is addressing multiple fairness criteria will converge to a Pareto efficient solution, besting other approaches by using fairness regularization and adversarial training.

Label assessment in topic models implicitly assume that the quality of a topic label is single-dimensional. In contrast, this work, supervised by Prof. Eric Baumer and published at CIKM 2022, provides evidence that human assessments about the quality of topic labels consist of multiple latent dimensions. This evidence comes from human assessments of four simple labeling techniques.  Subsequent analysis demonstrates that this multi-item, two-factor assessment can reveal nuances that would be missed using either a single-item human assessment of perceived label quality or established performance metrics.

The recent development and popularity of alternative processing architectures give rise to the creation of algorithms with high-performance data structures.  This work, supervised by Prof. Roberto Palmieri and presented at the International Conference on Distributed Computing and Networking in 2021, introduces a modular and elastic framework that simplifies the development of high-performance concurrent data structures that support linearizable primitive (i.e., add, remove, contains) and bulk (e.g., range query) operations.
